briefdescription.para: Signature for a cbprintf callback function.

listitem.para: c a character to output. The output behavior should be as if this was cast to an unsigned char.
ctx a pointer to an object that provides context for the output operation.

detaileddescription.para: The declaration does not specify the parameter types. This allows a function like fputc to be used without requiring all context pointers to be to a FILE object.

simplesect.para: the value of c cast to an unsigned char then back to int, or a negative error code that will be returned from cbprintf().

memberdef.definition: typedef int(* cbvprintf_exteral_formatter_func) (cbprintf_cb out, void *ctx, const char *fmt, va_list ap)
memberdef.argsstring: )(cbprintf_cb out, void *ctx, const char *fmt, va_list ap)
memberdef.name: cbvprintf_exteral_formatter_func

briefdescription.para: Signature for a external formatter function identical to cbvprintf.

detaileddescription.para: This function expects the following parameters:

parameterdescription.para: the function used to emit each generated character.
a pointer to an object that provides context for the external formatter.
a standard ISO C format string with characters and conversion specifications.
captured stack arguments corresponding to the conversion specifications found within fmt.

simplesect.para: vprintf like return values: the number of characters printed, or a negative error value returned from external formatter.

memberdef.argsstring: (void *packaged, size_t len, uint32_t flags, const char *format,...)
memberdef.name: cbprintf_package

briefdescription.para: Capture state required to output formatted data later.

detaileddescription.para: Like cbprintf() but instead of processing the arguments and emitting the formatted results immediately all arguments are captured so this can be done in a different context, e.g. when the output function can block.

In addition to the values extracted from arguments this will ensure that copies are made of the necessary portions of any string parameters that are not confirmed to be stored in read-only memory (hence assumed to be safe to refer to directly later).

parameterdescription.para: pointer to where the packaged data can be stored. Pass a null pointer to store nothing but still calculate the total space required. The data stored here is relocatable, that is it can be moved to another contiguous block of memory. However, under condition that alignment is maintained. It must be aligned to at least the size of a pointer.

this must be set to the number of bytes available at packaged if it is not null. If packaged is null then it indicates hypothetical buffer alignment offset in bytes compared to CBPRINTF_PACKAGE_ALIGNMENT alignment. Buffer alignment offset impacts returned size of the package. Xtensa requires that buffer is always aligned to CBPRINTF_PACKAGE_ALIGNMENT so it must be multiply of CBPRINTF_PACKAGE_ALIGNMENT or 0 when packaged is null.
option flags. See Package flags..
a standard ISO C format string with characters and conversion specifications.
arguments corresponding to the conversion specifications found within format.
the number of bytes successfully stored at packaged. This will not exceed len.
if format is not acceptable
if packaged alignment is not acceptable
if packaged was not null and the space required to store exceed len.

memberdef.argsstring: (void *packaged, size_t len, uint32_t flags, const char *format, va_list ap)
memberdef.name: cbvprintf_package

briefdescription.para: Capture state required to output formatted data later.

detaileddescription.para: Like cbprintf() but instead of processing the arguments and emitting the formatted results immediately all arguments are captured so this can be done in a different context, e.g. when the output function can block.

In addition to the values extracted from arguments this will ensure that copies are made of the necessary portions of any string parameters that are not confirmed to be stored in read-only memory (hence assumed to be safe to refer to directly later).

parameterdescription.para: pointer to where the packaged data can be stored. Pass a null pointer to store nothing but still calculate the total space required. The data stored here is relocatable, that is it can be moved to another contiguous block of memory. The pointer must be aligned to a multiple of the largest element in the argument list.
this must be set to the number of bytes available at packaged. Ignored if packaged is NULL.
option flags. See Package flags..
a standard ISO C format string with characters and conversion specifications.
captured stack arguments corresponding to the conversion specifications found within format.
the number of bytes successfully stored at packaged. This will not exceed len.
if format is not acceptable
if packaged was not null and the space required to store exceed len.

briefdescription.para: Convert package to fully self-contained (fsc) package.

detaileddescription.para: By default, package does not contain read only strings. However, if needed it may be converted to a fully self-contained package which contains all strings. In order to allow such conversion, original package must be created with CBPRINTF_PACKAGE_ADD_STRING_IDXS flag. Such package will contain necessary data to find read only strings in the package and copy them into package body.

parameterdescription.para: pointer to original package created with CBPRINTF_PACKAGE_ADD_STRING_IDXS.
in_packaged length.
pointer to location where fully self-contained version of the input package will be written. Pass a null pointer to calculate space required.
must be set to the number of bytes available at packaged. Not used if packaged is null.
the number of bytes successfully stored at packaged. This will not exceed len. If packaged is null, calculated length.
if packaged was not null and the space required to store exceed len.
if in_packaged is null.

briefdescription.para: Generate the output for a previously captured format operation using an external formatter.

parameterdescription.para: the function used to emit each generated character.
external formatter function.
a pointer to an object that provides context for the external formatter.
the data required to generate the formatted output, as captured by cbprintf_package() or cbvprintf_package(). The alignment requirement on this data is the same as when it was initially created.

simplesect.para: Memory indicated by packaged will be modified in a non-destructive way, meaning that it could still be reused with this function again.
printf like return values: the number of characters printed, or a negative error value returned from external formatter.

detaileddescription.para: This is essentially printf() except the output is generated character-by-character using the provided out function. This allows formatting text of unbounded length without incurring the cost of a temporary buffer.
All formatting specifiers of C99 are recognized, and most are supported if the functionality is enabled.

simplesect.para: The functionality of this function is significantly reduced when embed:rst:inline :kconfig:option:`CONFIG_CBPRINTF_NANO` is selected.

parameterdescription.para: the function used to emit each generated character.
context provided when invoking out
a standard ISO C format string with characters and conversion specifications.
arguments corresponding to the conversion specifications found within format.

simplesect.para: the number of characters printed, or a negative error value returned from invoking out.

memberdef.argsstring: (cbprintf_cb out, void *ctx, const char *format, va_list ap)
memberdef.name: cbvprintf

detaileddescription.para: This is essentially vsprintf() except the output is generated character-by-character using the provided out function. This allows formatting text of unbounded length without incurring the cost of a temporary buffer.

simplesect.para: This function is available only when embed:rst:inline :kconfig:option:`CONFIG_CBPRINTF_LIBC_SUBSTS` is selected.
The functionality of this function is significantly reduced when embed:rst:inline :kconfig:option:`CONFIG_CBPRINTF_NANO` is selected.

parameterdescription.para: the function used to emit each generated character.
context provided when invoking out
a standard ISO C format string with characters and conversion specifications.
a reference to the values to be converted.

simplesect.para: the number of characters generated, or a negative error value returned from invoking out.

simplesect.para: Memory indicated by packaged will be modified in a non-destructive way, meaning that it could still be reused with this function again.
the number of characters printed, or a negative error value returned from invoking out.

parameterdescription.para: where the formatted content should be written
maximum number of chaacters for the formatted output, including the terminating null byte.
a standard ISO C format string with characters and conversion specifications.

simplesect.para: The number of characters that would have been written to str, excluding the terminating null byte. This is greater than the number actually written if size is too small.

memberdef.argsstring: (char *str, size_t size, const char *format, va_list ap)
memberdef.name: vsnprintfcb

simplesect.para: This function is available only when embed:rst:inline :kconfig:option:`CONFIG_CBPRINTF_LIBC_SUBSTS` is selected.
The functionality of this function is significantly reduced when embed:rst:inline :kconfig:option:`CONFIG_CBPRINTF_NANO` is selected.

parameterdescription.para: where the formatted content should be written
maximum number of chaacters for the formatted output, including the terminating null byte.
a standard ISO C format string with characters and conversion specifications.
a reference to the values to be converted.

simplesect.para: The number of characters that would have been written to str, excluding the terminating null byte. This is greater than the number actually written if size is too small.

briefdescription.para: Required alignment of the buffer used for packaging.
Determine if string must be packaged in run time.

detaileddescription.para: Static packaging can be applied if size of the package can be determined at compile time. In general, package size can be determined at compile time if there are no string arguments which might be copied into package body if they are considered transient.

simplesect.para: By default any char pointers are considered to be pointing at transient strings. This can be narrowed down to non const pointers by using CBPRINTF_MUST_RUNTIME_PACKAGE_CONST_CHAR.

parameterdescription.para: number of read only string arguments in the parameter list. It shall be non-zero if there are known read only string arguments present in the string (e.g. function name prefix in the log message).
String with arguments.
option flags. See Package flags..
if string must be packaged in run time.
string can be statically packaged.

detaileddescription.para: Build string package from formatted string. It assumes that formatted string is in the read only memory.
If _Generic is not supported then runtime packaging is performed.

parameterdescription.para: pointer to where the packaged data can be stored. Pass a null pointer to skip packaging but still calculate the total space required. The data stored here is relocatable, that is it can be moved to another contiguous block of memory. It must be aligned to the size of the longest argument. It is recommended to use CBPRINTF_PACKAGE_ALIGNMENT for alignment.
set to the number of bytes available at packaged. If packaged is NULL the value is ignored.
variable updated to the number of bytes required to completely store the packed information. If input buffer was too small it is set to -ENOSPC.

input buffer alignment offset in bytes. Where offset 0 means that buffer is aligned to CBPRINTF_PACKAGE_ALIGNMENT. Xtensa requires that packaged is aligned to CBPRINTF_PACKAGE_ALIGNMENT so it must be multiply of CBPRINTF_PACKAGE_ALIGNMENT or 0.
option flags. See Package flags..
formatted string with arguments. Format string must be constant.
